text.name: sys_description
text.text: The Commodore 64 is a personal computer designed by Jack Tramiel's firm in 1982. It was the best-selling model of its decade with over 13 million units sold worldwide. It uses an 8-bit 6510 microprocessor and features 64KB of RAM. Its graphics chip, the VIC-II, provides 6 colors with hardware scrolling backgrounds. Its sound chip, SID, had three voices, several waveforms, sound modules and filtering capabilities (its designer, Bob Yannes, would go on to be the co-founder of the synthesizer company Ensoniq). To say it was advanced for its time would be an understatement.
